page.title: 03LAYER_DE_LA_HAYE
page.content: against raiding parties from the coast. Later the name becomes Leire or Leger which means 'mud'. This is a Scandinavian or Norse word and may have been used to describe the soil and the marsh_land around the village. By the time of the Norman Conquest Layer was in use,which roughly translated means 'owned by' and the 'de_la_Haye' was added when a member of that family owned a substantial amount of land.The de la Hayes were generous benefactors of the Abbey of St.John in Colchester and the monks from there took services in the church. The plague of the fourteenth century, known as the 'Black Death',decimated the village and the church became derelict until it was restored by the monks.
